Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. In response to an increase in the frequency of thunderstorms that produce damaging hail, some apple growers have started to cover their apple orchards with large nets. While these nets protect the apple trees from hail damage, the nets also decrease the amount of light that reaches the trees. In an attempt to reduce the impact of shading by the nets, researchers investigated the ability of different ground covers placed around the base of the trees to reflect light back to the apple trees. An apple orchard with genetically identical apple trees was divided in half. A reflective ground cover was applied to one half of the orchard, while grass was left as the ground cover for the other half. A sample of apples was taken from every tree. The percent of light reflected by the two ground covers was measured at three distances above the ground (Figure 1). Figure 1. Percent of light reflected by ground covers, measured at three distances above the ground. Error bars equal <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The amount of light that apple trees receive changes the expression of a certain transcription factor. This transcription factor affects the transcription rate of the gene encoding the enzyme phenylalanine ammonium-lyase (<math alttext="P A L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). The <math alttext="P A L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> enzyme is required for the production of two types of pigments, anthocyanins and flavonoids, which contribute to the coloration of apples. Light also affects the activity of the <math alttext="P A L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> enzyme by a signal transduction pathway (Figure 2). Figure 2. Simplified model of the signal transduction pathway leading to <math alttext="P A L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activation and breakdown The researchers measured the average concentrations of anthocyanins and flavonoids in apples from trees grown with both types of ground cover (Table 1). (c) Researchers also study apple trees that have been genetically modified so that the <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> binding domain of the transcription factor that stimulates expression of the <math alttext="P A L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> enzyme has been deleted. The researchers repeat the ground cover experiment with the genetically modified apple trees. Predict the effect of the two ground covers on pigment concentrations in the genetically modified apples. Provide reasoning to justify your prediction.

(d) Based on the information provided in Figure 2, predict the effect of a constantly active kinase on flavonoid pigment production. In leaves, the <math alttext="P A L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> enzyme is also required for the production of other pigment molecules that are capable of absorbing <math alttext="U V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and other radiation from the sun. Explain how the relationship between light and pigment production might serve as a protective mechanism for the cells of the apple tree. Explain how the <math alttext="P A L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PAL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> enzyme interacts with its substrate in the absence of light.
